nodes.text: Automatically identifying and prioritizing input-sensitive "incubative" instructions for selective instruction duplication (SID) improves SDC coverage of HPC applications when they run with multiple program inputs
Existing SID methods evaluate protection effectiveness using a single reference input and assume program error-resilience is similar across inputs
A small subset of instructions, called incubative instructions, exhibit drastically different error-propagation behaviors across inputs and cause large losses in SDC coverage when inputs change

MINPSID, an automated framework, identifies incubative instructions via static analysis plus guided input search and re-prioritizes them in SID instruction selection to improve multi-input SDC coverage

We model transient hardware faults as single-bit flips injected to LLVM IR instruction return values and measure per-instruction SDC probabilities and program-level SDC coverage via LLVM-level fault injection (LLFI)
We evaluate with 11 CPU benchmarks (Rodinia, FFT, HPCCG, Xsbench), 50 random valid inputs per benchmark (with filters), and protection budgets of 30%, 50%, 70% using Knapsack-based SID selection

Fault-injection experiments show existing SID's expected SDC coverage (measured on reference input) can drop drastically across inputs, e.g., average coverage falls from 96.12% to 58.76% over 11 benchmarks
Observed behavior: in some benchmarks increasing SID protection level can paradoxically decrease minimum measured SDC coverage across inputs

Analysis shows incubative instructions have near-zero measured benefit (SDC probability times cost) on reference input but much higher SDC probability on other inputs, so they are not selected by SID yet cause most coverage loss
Quantitative incubative-instruction statistics: incubatives range from 6.20% to 32.09% of static instructions (average 15.79%) and are responsible for at least 97% of SDC coverage loss

MINPSID input-search engine uses a genetic algorithm that mutates/crosses inputs and compares dynamically weighted CFGs (basic-block execution counts) to prioritize inputs that exercise different control flows

MINPSID identifies incubative instructions by running per-instruction FI on the generated inputs and comparing per-instruction SDC probabilities to prior inputs, then updates incubatives' benefits to observed upper bounds before running Knapsack

Evaluation results: MINPSID reduces SDC coverage loss substantially (mitigates 97% of baseline loss on average), narrows coverage variance across inputs, and provides more conservative expected coverage
MINPSID finds 45.60% more incubative instructions than a random input-search baseline within the same time budget, improving identification efficiency and reducing required FIs

Overhead: MINPSID incurs a one-time analysis cost (average 63.71 minutes per benchmark on the authors' machines) dominated by per-instruction FIs and input search; existing SID preparation is ~3.87 minutes

Conclusion: Re-prioritizing incubative instructions identified by guided input search effectively hardens SID against multi-input SDC-coverage loss, with acceptable one-time analysis cost and potential for parallelization and future extension to accelerators
